No, the two balls would not fall at the same speed unless in a vacuum. Here is why:

Lets look at Newtons 2nd Law: The sum of all forces (F_tot) on an object is equal to mass * acceleration of that object <=> F_tot=m*a. 

Let's look at this law only in the direction of gravity: You have two opposing forces that act in that direction under realistic conditions: Gravitational force F_g=m*g and Drag Force F_d which depends on the bodies shape, speed and - yes NOT mass! 
BUT, if we now look at Newton's Second law and rearange it a bit you will see:
a= F_tot/m = g - F_d/m

Therefore if your ball is very heavy, the Drag Force F_d has almost no impact on the acceleration since it is divided by m. Therefore a heavy ball accelerates more than a light ball (e.g. a balloon) towards earth. Both balls however will eventually reach a different terminal velocity, since the Drag Force F_d will increase with the square of the speed and thus oppose the acceleration of the ball more and more. Note that in a vaccum the drag Force would be 0. Therefore F_d = 0 and then the acceleration would no longer depend on the mass of the object. This is actually a misconception of another misconception. A heavier ball will always fall slightly faster although not measurable by any means. In regular atmosphere, some of this can be attributed to terminal velocity, but a heavier ball will always fall faster even in a vacuum. This effect is derived from Newton's second and third law of motion. This classical physics problem can be modeled. Newton's law of universal gravitation gives the equation Between the gravitational force between two objects with mass in relation to their masses and distance of separation. Since force is also modeled by force=mass*acceleration, you can equate the two equations. Mass of object cancels out leaving acceleration right? So all objects will fall at an accelerating rate of 9.8 m/s/s right? Wrong. This neglects the acceleration of the earth to the object. Newton's third law states that the object will also exert an equal force on the earth, so the earth will also accelerate towards the ball, leaving a smaller distance between them per time unit, which ultimately repeats itself but this time by the distance being smaller, so the gravitational force being larger and thus the acceleration being larger. Realistically, the difference is so small, that it cannot be measured except for objects with near similar mass of the earth, but nonetheless it still is a fact.

Nope. This video is wrong. Yes, for objects as small as those balls the effect is infinitesimally small, so it SEEMS like they fall at the same rate. But the gravitational force between two objects is determined by BOTH objects, by both the individual ball that's falling and the Earth that it's falling towards. So there is more gravitational pull between the "heavier" ball and Earth than there is between the "lighter" ball and the Earth.

The mistake is in thinking that it's only the Earth that exerts the gravity. But it's not. Rather, it's the composite mutual attraction between the Earth and a ball, or any other falling object.

Take one of those balls up to the Moon and drop it. It falls at a much slower acceleration than on Earth. Now, take the Moon and hold it a few feet above the surface of the Earth and drop it. Will it fall at Earth's gravitational rate (32 feet per second per second) or at the Moon's gravitational rate (about 1/6 of Earth's)? Clearly it's the composite gravitational forces from both objects that determine the acceleration.

THUS, the more massive ball will indeed FALL FASTER than the lighter ball. It's just that the difference is so infinitesimally small that it's unnoticeable in the simple experiments shown in the video.

Another way to think this problem through, is to think of each ball as a collection of individual atoms or particles. When at rest (not falling), the particles are supported by each other and thus the weight of each atom/particle is added to the one below it. The bottom atom/particle will be supporting the weight of the entire ball (i.e. its mass). However when falling, each atom/particle is affected equally, regardless of the size of the collection it is a part of. The bottom atom/particle is no longer affected by the mass of the other atoms/particles.
Another proof of this phenomenon is shown by the velocity of satellites. Regardless of the mass of the satellite, the velocity that it must travel at in order to stay in orbit is determined by the distance from the center of the Earth. To be exact, the formula would be the square root of the distance multiplied by the acceleration of gravity at that distance (yes it's different than on the surface). Take notice that the mass of the object is not mentioned in the equation at all.

Eventually, the drag force upward on the object will be equal to the downward force of gravity (9.8 Newtons of drag).  At this point, the net force on the object is zero, so there is no acceleration.  This is terminal velocity.  As you can easily see, you are wrong in thinking that an object will continue to accelerate at 9.8 m/s² even though the drag force is increasing as the velocity through the air is increasing, and then suddenly stop accelerating.  It just doesn't work that way.

In other words, lets say an object has a mass of 10kg.  The force from gravity (near the surface) is 9.8 Newtons.  At the beginning of the fall, there is virtually 0 force due to drag, so the net force is 9.8 Newtons downward.  The acceletion would be 9.8 m/s² downward.  Now after about 1 second, lets say the force of drag is now 5 Newtons.  That's 9.8 downward due to gravity, and 5 upward due to drag for a net force of 4.8 Newtons downward - so the acceleration is then 4.8 m/s² downward.

This is incorrect.  You are under the false impression that objects will accelerate at a constant rate until they reach their terminal velocities and then suddenly stop accelerating.  This is not how it works.  For objects falling in a medium that produces a drag force, the net acceleration is constantly decreasing as the velocity of that object throught the medium is inreasing.  The net force on the object is decreasing(drag - gravity) - so the net acceleration will also decrease in proportion.

While drag may not depend DIRECTLY on mass, when it comes to falling objects, it INDIRECTLY depends on mass.  In general, a more massive object will fall faster through air - which means it travels faster through air - and drag is proportional to the velocity through the air.  This means that the drag will be greater on more massive bodies (in general).  Also rememeber that the resulting acceleration of that drag force certainly depends DIRECTLY on the mass of the body.

Two objects of the same size and shape will only have the same force of drag if they are traveling through the same medium at the same relative velocity to that medium.
